section.name: Nabla plugins
section.p: Nabla features can be extended by adding components called plugins. Their purpose is to integrate the different features but share a common installation mode. The common steps in order to install a plugin are :

ul.li: Unzip the binary distribution of the plugin in the webapp folder
[ optional] Execute scripts to create and/or initialize the tables associated to the plugin (Cf. below is to locate those scripts in different distribution )
[ optional ] Configure the property file of the plugin
[ optional ] Configure the db.properties file of Nabla to add a new specific connection pool to the plugin
Connect to admin and go to the "Plugin Management" feature
The new plugin is deactivated in the plugin list. Click to activate proper installation.
[ optional ] Selection the connection pool possibly used by the plugin.

subsection.name: The extensions brought by the plugins
subsection.p: Many types of extension are available :
A plugin can contain one or more extension types. For example, it can introduce a new type of portlet and two administrative functions to manage this portlet type.
In summary, a plugin may contain :

ul.li: 0 to n specific CSS style sheets
0 to 1 indexing link services of type LinkService
0 to 1 insertion services of type HtmlService

subsection.name: Plugins and databases
subsection.p: The plugin can access to two databases. It can access to the Nabla database through the AppConnectionService class. , but it is also possible to affect a specific connection pool by declaring it in the db.properties during the installation phase.

subsection.name: Plugins loading
subsection.p: The plugins are loaded when starting the webapp by the PluginService which searches for all XML files found in the /WEB-INF/plugins folder. To prevent loading of a plugin, the XML file must be removed from the folder.
The data concerning the local status(state installed/not-installed, specific connection pool, ...) are recorded in the plugins.dat located in the same folder.

If a plugin has a "properties" file, it must be placed into the /WEB-INF/conf/plugins folder. The property files will be automatically loaded and added to all the properties of the application. They will be accessible by means of AppPropertiesService. All plugin properties must be prefixed by the name of the plugin to avoid internal conflict.

subsection.name: Plugin Files
subsection.p: A plugin may need a large set of different file types.Here are the folders designed to contain these files.

tr.td: The JSPs used for administrative purpose
The accessible JSPs from the portal
Images used by the administration features
The images used for presentation purpose
The images managed as data by the plugin
The templates for the administrative features
The application's templates accessible from the portal
The jar files containing the classes of the plugin
The SQL scripts used to install and initialize tables of the plugin (binary distribution)

subsection.p: The organization of source files is follows :

tr.td: The java source files in the business layer
The java source files in the service layer
The java source files in the presentation layer
The linguistic resources of different message types
The installation SQL scripts and installation script ofthe plugin tables (source distribution)
Documentation in XML format for Maven

subsection.name: Configuration file for a plugin
subsection.p: The configuration file of the plugin is an XML file represented in the following structure :

div.pre:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ISO-8859-1"?> <plug-in> <name>myplugin</name> <class>com.nabla.project.portal.service.PluginDefaultImplementation</class> <version>1.0</version> <description>Plugin description</description> <provider>Mairie de Paris</provider> <provider-url>http://nabla.paris.fr</provider-url> <icon-url>../../images/admin/skin/plugins/myplugin/myplugin.gif</icon-url> <copyright>Copyright (c) 2001-2008 Mairie de Paris</copyright>
<!-- Does the plugin require a connection pool : 1 - yes, 0 - No --> <db-pool-required>1</db-pool-required>
<!-- Specific CSS style sheets eventually used --> <css-stylesheets> <css-stylesheet>myplugin/myplugin.css</css-stylesheet> </css-stylesheets>
<!-- Specific scripts eventually used --> <javascript-files> <javascript-file>myplugin/myplugin.css</javascript-file> </javascript-files>
<!-- List of administrative features eventually intreoduced be the plugin--> <admin-features> <admin-feature> <feature-id>MYFEATURE_MANAGEMENT</feature-id> <feature-title>My Feature</feature-title> <feature-description>Description of my feature</feature-description> <feature-level>3</feature-level> <feature-url>plugins/myplugin/ManageMyFeature.jsp</feature-url> </admin-feature> ... </admin-features>
<!-- Portlets List eventually added by the plugin--> <portlets> <portlet> <portlet-class>com.nabla.project.plugins.myportlet.business.portlet.MyPortletHome</portlet-class> <portlet-type-name>MyNew Portlet</portlet-type-name> <portlet-creation-url>plugins/article/CreatePortletMyPortlet.jsp</portlet-creation-url> <portlet-update-url>plugins/article/ModifyPortletMyPortlet.jsp</portlet-update-url> </portlet> ... </portlets>
<!-- Applications made of XPages and evantually by a plugin --> <applications> <application> <application-id>app_page_name</application-id> <application-class>com.nabla.project.plugins.myplugin.web.MyPluginApp</application-class> <application-roles>role1,role2</application-roles> </application> </applications>
<!-- Content Service --> <content-service> <content-service-class>com.nabla.project.plugins.myplugin.service.MyContentService</content-service-class> </content-service>
<!-- Links Service --> <link-service> <link-service-id>mylinkservice</link-service-id> <link-service-class>com.nabla.project.plugins.mylinkservice.service.MyLinkService</link-service-class> <link-service-bean-class>com.nabla.project.plugins.mylinkservice.web.MyLinkServiceJspBean</link-service-bean-class> <link-service-label>Link to my URIs</link-service-label> </link-service>
</plug-in>

subsection.p: A plugin dtd is availabe in the /WEB-INF/plugins folder from Nabla WebApp.

subsection.name: Modules
subsection.p: Some plugins need their own plugins. These are called modules. The plugins such as mynabla,formengine and codewizard have modules.
The rules concerning the modules are the following :
